ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HDB FLAT OWNER-OCCUPIERS
(Arrears of instalment payments)


    1. Mr Chin Harn Tong asked the Minister for National Development how many owner-occupiers of Housing and Development Board flats are in arrears with their instalment payments as at the latest convenient date; and to what extent were they in arrears during 1988.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 31st December 1988, 34,178 out of a total of 328,903 (or 10.4%) owner-occupiers of HDB flats with mortgage accounts were in arrears with their loan instalment payments. Out of these, 67% owed less than three months, 17% owed between three to six months and 16% owed more than six months of instalments.

HAWKERS PENALIZED UNDER THE POINTS DEMERIT SYSTEM


    3. Mr Chin Harn Tong asked the Minister for the Environment (a) how many hawkers in food centres have been

Column: 640

penalised under the Points Demerit System since its inception up to the latest convenient date; (b) which food centres have the greatest number of offending hawkers; and (c) whether he is satisfied that the scheme has improved the conduct of hawkers.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister for the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Since the implementation of the Points Demerit System on 14th September 1987, a total of 660 hawkers in hawker centres, 121 stallholders in eating houses, 37 snack bar operators and five restaurant managements have been given demerit points.

    So far, six hawkers and three snack bar operators have had their licences suspended for two weeks. Another six cases involving hawkers are pending suspension.

    The hawker centres with the greatest number of offenders are the Telok Ayer Transit Centre, Cuppage Road Market, Golden Mile Food Centre, Newton Food Centre and Berseh Food Centre.

    I am satisfied that the scheme has improved the awareness of food vendors in general. They are more conscious of the need to keep their premises clean and to observe proper food and personal hygiene. Standards of cleanliness and hygiene in food centres have generally improved.

    My Ministry takes a serious view against recalcitrant food vendors who are indifferent to hygiene standards. Food vendors must understand their role and responsibilities. The Ministry is currently reviewing the Environmental Public Health (Food Establishment) Regulations and one of the amendments to be made will be to increase the penalties.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, stiffer penalties, the risk of losing one's licence or having it suspended, in addition to the adverse publicity generated, would deter restaurant operators and other food vendors from unhygienic practices.

Column: 641



     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC): Sir, will the Senior Parliamentary Secretary list out the names of the five restaurants which have been given demerit points, and also the names of the snack bars whose licences have been suspended? Secondly, can the Senior Parliamentary Secretary explain why an established Mayflower Peking Restaurant was given light penalty by the court recently for its food hygiene violation? And the third supplementary question: can the Senior Parliamentary Secretary assure this House that in future, violation of this nature will be given more severe penalty?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: First, the hon. Mr Chin wants me to list out the five restaurants and the snack bars that have been given demerit points. Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid I do not have the names of the restaurants and the snack bars. So I cannot provide him the answers. But if he wants, I can arrange to send them to him.

    The other question concerns Mayflower Restaurant. Why was this popular restaurant given such a light punishment, so to speak, by the court? Mr Speaker, Sir, first, we have to realize that we have no jurisdiction over the courts as to what they want to do or not want to do, in terms of meting out punishment. Secondly, I agree with him that, in today's context, the fines may not be a sufficient deterrent. But I would go on to say that we have to look at the whole system of punishment and not only one particular aspect of it. We have the demerit points system, we have the fines, we have adverse publicity. However, I cannot recall the case of Mayflower Restaurant as clearly as I can of the Kelong Restaurant. The Kelong committed certain offences in relation to public health regulations. They caused an outbreak of food poisioning. And what happened after that?

    Generally, I would think that only demerit points or stiffer penalties will deter restaurants such as Mayflower or Kelong from repeating offences like that or prevent them from being callous. But I think the important thing is that we realize many managements of such well-known restaurants are afraid of adverse publicity. And here I would compliment the press for doing their bit in terms of providing the type of publicity so that consumers are aware of the status of each restaurant that

Column: 642

is serving food to them. If the press had not come out with such publicity, I think Mr Chin would not have read about it. He would not have known about it. The fact that it was publicised gave everybody the knowledge that Mayflower, Kelong, well-known restaurants, were in trouble. In fact, when the Kelong case was publicised, we had calls the next day from various consumers, I suppose patrons of the restaurant, asking about the status with regard to Kelong itself. Why? Perhaps they were going to hold functions there or they wanted to hold birthday parties or wedding parties. "Should I go?" So the very fact that people are aware, and are afraid, is sufficient adverse publicity for the restaurants. I would also inform the Member that on several occasions when such things happen, the restaurants will be the first to come and tell us, "Please, if you can, do not give us adverse publicity."

    So I do not think that demerit points alone or a fine is sufficient to deter anybody. I think it is basically the total system that works. And we hope that all the systems that we have will deter restaurants like Kelong, Mayflower, or others who are callous to be more careful with the way they handle food.

    The other question is whether I can assure the House that violation of such a nature in future will be more severely punished. Yes, I can assure him. We will certainly ensure that in future we will make sure that people who are callous, and so on and so forth, with food handling practices will be duly punished. At the end of it all, I think the consumers have a part to play. The Government cannot play all this role by itself. Every Singaporean is a consumer, the silent majority. And if every Singaporean makes it a point to demand clean food, good food, then I think that we can together ensure that food sold in Singapore is clean and healthy.

TELEPHONE SERVICE
(Impact and cost to residential customers)


    4. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for Communications and Information what will be the impact on telephone service and the cost of that service to residential customers over the next 5 years

Column: 643

as a result of the recent reorganization of the Tele-communication Authority of Singapore.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Sir, the objective of restructuring Telecoms is to further improve its efficiency and its productivity, and to make the organization more responsive to the needs of its customers. Currently, Telecoms provides a service that is comparable to the best in the world by way of pricing, range of products and services and the sophistication of those products and services. For example, with pricing. In calls to countries all over the world, it is cheaper in a very large number of cases to make the call from Singapore to the other country than to have the call made the other way round. Sir, with your permission, I will ask the Clerk to circulate a short list (Cols. 715 - 716) of some of the rates that Singapore Telecoms charges and compare them with the rates for incoming calls. [Copies of Table circulated to Members.] Sir, the list shows that in a large number of cases, the rates charged by Singapore are much lower. In some cases, Telecoms' rates can be as low as half the rate for the incoming calls.
list - SINGAPORE IDD RATES VS. CORRESPONDING INCOMING RATES (Cols. 715 - 716)


    Telecoms' pricing philosophy is simple - to provide the best possible service at the lowest possible cost, subject to full recovery of the services provided. With increased efficiency and productivity resulting from this restructuring, we can keep the operation costs down and savings made can then be passed on to the consumers, as had been done over the last 10 years.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, is the residential service to the consumers currently being subsidized? Would the reorganization not give Singapore Telecom an exact measure of that subsidy, if it exists?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, it is not possible to say whether the local services are being subsidized by the international services, because of the overlap in the use of the infrastructure provided. For example, the same network of lines between homes in

Column: 644

Singapore is also used for calls from those homes to countries overseas. So it is not possible under our present practice to have a clear partition of all cost factors. These costs are partitioned in a manner that is generally acceptable internationally.

MEDICAL BENEFITS FOR WIDOWS OF GOVERNMENT PENSIONERS


    5. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Finance whether he will allow the wives of government pensioners to continue enjoying medical benefits after the death of the pensioners.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have mentioned before in this House in 1986, medical benefits are extended to the pensioner and his wife because of the continuing relationship between the pensioner and the Government as his former employer by virtue of the pension payable to him. When the pensioner dies, his pension stops and his eligibility for medical benefits for his wife will also cease.

    Since April 1986, all appointments in the Civil Service except those in the Designated Services are made non-pensionable in order to reduce the long-term burden of Government. If we were to provide medical care for the existing number of around 6,500 pensioners' wives for approximately five years, which is the estimated period whereby females might outlive the males, the estimated cost to Government could exceed $40 million. In view of the cost which ultimately must pass on to the taxpayers, there is a limit to which the Government can continue to take care of the welfare of pensioners and their family members. Therefore, the Government is not able to change the long established rule that the wives of Government pensioners do not enjoy medical benefits after the death of the pensioners.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson): Sir, does the Minister have the percentage figure of the additional cost to Government versus the total cost of benefits that are given to the civil service as a whole in a year? If the percentage is very small,

Column: 645

would the Minister not consider in favour of the pensioners who have served the Government diligently for their whole life?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I do not have the percentage figure in hand. The principle is not so much whether it is a small percentage or large percentage. As long as we are responsible for the disbursement of public funds, I think we have to draw the line somewhere, the principle being that if we extend on these grounds for one category of requests, it would be very difficult not to do the same for others.

Column: 645

MEDICAL BENEFITS FOR DEPENDANTS OF FEMALE PUBLIC SECTOR EMPLOYEES


    6. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Finance what is the present stage of the feasibility study carried out by his Ministry on medical benefits for dependants of female employees in the public sector.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of Finance has reviewed the question of medical benefits for dependants of female officers and has decided to adopt a liberal approach in granting such benefits to female officers who are sole supporters of their families. This means that female officers who are divorced, widowed or granted a decree of judicial separation will in future be automatically granted medical benefits for their dependants. The benefits would also be granted in other cases where the female officers are the sole supporters of their families, as in cases where the spouses cannot work for health reasons.

ASSISTANCE TO LOCAL ENTREPRENEURS IN 1988
(Progress report)


    8. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if he will give a progress report of assistance rendered to local entrepreneurs during 1988 in terms of (i) the amount of grants and cheap loans extended, (ii) the number of local companies that have benefited from such financial assistance, and (iii) the kind of assistance and results extended by the Trade Development Board, Economic Development Board and Singapore Institute of Standards and Industrial Research.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, the Government's assistance schemes to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are comprehensive. They are designed to help local SMEs gain access to financing, fixed capital investments, technology and know-how.

    The major financial assistance schemes which Members are familiar with include:

    (i) Small Industries Finance Scheme (SIFS);

    (ii) Liberalised Investment Allowance Scheme (LIAS);

    (iii) Small Industry Technical Assistance Scheme (SITAS);

    (iv) Business Development Scheme (BDS);

    (v) Market Development Assistance Scheme (MDAS);

Column: 647



    (vi) Product Development Assistance Scheme (PDAS);

    (vii) Design Venture Programme.

    As at the end of 1988, there were 8,719 cases of direct financial assistance given to local SMEs under the above schemes. This amounted to some $1.38 billion. Details are given in the Table (Cols. 717 - 718) that I have circulated to Members.
Table - SUMMARY TABLE OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE GIVEN TO SMALL AND MEDIUM-SIZED ENTERPRISES (Cols. 717 - 718)


    Aside from the financial assistance schemes, the Government also provides developmental assistance to local SMEs. These schemes include:

    Local Industry Upgrading Programme (LIUP) which helps SMEs in our supporting industries upgrade, by helping to forge ties between them and multi-national corporations (MNCs) in Singapore. So far, 21 MNCs have teamed up with the EDB to upgrade their local suppliers. Eight of these MNCs have implemented the scheme fully, providing assistance to 58 local SMEs.

    Another developmental assistance scheme is what we call the Technology Adoption and Automation Programmes which include schemes implemented by SISIR such as technology promotion and information services, competence centres for contract R&D, consultancy, testing and technical services, incubator units for technology innovation and quality upgrading services to meet export requirements.

    The results of all these financial and developmental assistance schemes are becoming visible. The participation rate in these schemes is high. By helping to reduce the financial and technological risks, these schemes have raised the confidence of local entrepreneurs. This is reflected in the significant increase in the value of local investment commitments from $295.1 million in 1987 to $347.8 million last year. The number of local enterprises also increased substantially from 64,200 to more than 71,000 over the same period.

SKILLS DEVELOPMENT FUND
(Particulars for 1988)


    9. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for Trade and Industry, in respect of the Skills Development Fund for the year 1988, (i) how much was collected, (ii) how much was paid out for the training of workers and managers, and (iii) how many of them were trained.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

Altogether 274,000 training places were taken up by these programmes in 1988.

MEDISAVE FOR ANNUAL MEDICAL CHECK-UPS


    10. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Acting Minister for Health whether he will allow the use of Medisave for annual medical check-ups.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Medisave scheme was introduced specifically to meet the hospitalization needs of the average Singaporean worker and his immediate family. Since the implementation of the scheme in 1984, my Ministry has already extended Medisave to cover services not originally considered such as day surgery, radiotherapy and expenses incurred for delivery of the third child. My Ministry plans to also extend Medisave to cover the catastrophic illness insurance scheme. My Ministry currently has no plan to further extend the usage of Medisave. We need to be sure that the current 6% Medisave contribution rate could still provide adequate savings to meet the individual's hospitalization needs during his or her old age before considering any further extension on the use of Medisave.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, may I ask the Minister whether he will agree that allowing the CPF depositors to use their money for annual medical check-ups, is, in fact, a form of preventive medicine, as it may help to alleviate their need for hospitalization in the future? The end result is that there will be lesser hospitalization cost being incurred than if you do not allow them to use their CPF for their annual medical check-ups.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, my Ministry recognizes the need for preventive medical care and that is why we have a very comprehensive preventive health education programme which includes encouragement on the use of screening services. However, that does not mean that Singaporeans need to have the use of Medisave before they make use of the screening services.

BETTER RACIAL MIX IN HDB HOUSING ESTATES
(Statement by the Minister for National Development)


     Mr S. Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, in a speech to community leaders on 6th January, I referred to the trend in some HDB estates where concentrations of racial groups are beginning to form. The President, in his Address to Parliament, also highlighted the gravity of this problem.

    I would like to inform the House today of the measures that the Government is going to introduce to ensure a better racial mix in HDB estates.

    The Government will set a limit on the maximum proportion allowed for each racial group in each HDB neighbourhood. It will also set a separate limit on the maximum proportion for each block. These limits are set out in Table 1 (Cols. 723 - 726). Some Tables and Annexes have already been distributed to Members. May I ask them to turn to Table 1? I will take them very briefly through this Table. Table 1 sets out the proportions of flats permitted for each race, each neighbourhood and block. You can see from this Table that for Malays who comprise 15% of the population, the permissible proportion of flats in each neighbourhood is 22% and for each block is 25%. For Chinese who comprise 76% of the population, the permissible proportion in each neighbourhood is 84% and in each block is 87%. And for Indians and others who make up about 9% of the population, the permissible proportion for each neighbourhood is 10% and for each block is 13%. These limits will cover the allocation of new flats as well as the sale of resale flats. They will take effect from 1st March 1989.
Table 1 - PROPORTIONS OF FLATS PERMITTED FOR EACH RACE IN EACH NEIGHBOURHOOD AND BLOCK, NEIGHBOURHOODS AFFECTED BY LIMITS SPECIFIED IN TABLE 1 AS AT 15 FEB 89 (Cols. 723 - 726)


    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to give the assurance that no HDB owner, whether he is Chinese, Malay or Indian will be requested to move from his present flat. The measures that we will be introducing to ensure a good racial mix will only affect

Column: 651
